thread.title: Indian Navy Rescues U.S. Ship Crew Amid Houthi Attacks in Gulf of Aden
thread.title_full: Indian Navy Rescues U.S. Ship Crew Amid Houthi Attacks in Gulf of Aden

author: Rhonna Morala
title: Indian Navy Rescues U.S. Ship Crew Amid Houthi Attacks in Gulf of Aden
text:
The Indian Navy has come to the rescue of a U.S. ship crew in the Gulf of Aden following an attack by the Houthi group from Yemen.
Houthi Trade Disruptions In Backdrop
These incidents are part of a series of Houthi assaults on trade ships in the Red Sea, leading to disruptions in vital sea routes and impacting global trade, according to reports from Reuters and U.S. News.
Houthi Attack On The Genco Picardy
Late on Wednesday, the Houthi group targeted the Genco Picardy, triggering a swift response from the U.S. military, which launched strikes on 14 Houthi missiles.
Read More:
These “Trump” Stocks Could Take Off if He’s Re-elected
Many Such Attacks
This attack is just one of many in a series that the Houthis have conducted in and around the Red Sea since November.
Houthi Threat To Global Trade
The Houthi militia, known for its alignment with Iran, has been focusing its attacks on ships in the Red Sea, directly affecting trade routes connecting Asia and Europe.
Supporting Palestine
The Houthis claim to support Palestinians in the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas militants in Gaza, and they have threatened to target U.S. ships in retaliation for actions taken by the United States and the United Kingdom.
Also Read:
GOP Presidential Candidate Arrested on Federal Tax Charges
In response to the crisis, India swiftly diverted a warship already deployed in the region to rescue the 22 crew members aboard the Genco Picardy, which included nine Indians.
All Crew Members Safe
Fortunately, all crew members were reported as safe, and a fire on the vessel had been successfully extinguished. The Houthi group claimed that their missiles had scored a “direct hit” on the bulk carrier.
Disruptions In Global Trade Routes
These repeated attacks on shipping routes in the Gulf of Aden and the Red Sea, accounting for approximately 15% of global shipping traffic, have far-reaching consequences for global trade.
Read More:
North Korea Fires Artillery Shells Near Border with South Korea; Leader’s Sister Mocks Seoul
Rerouting Of Vessels
Major shipping companies, such as Maersk, have been compelled to reroute vessels away from the Red Sea, opting for longer routes around Africa or temporarily suspending operations until the safety of their vessels can be guaranteed.
International Response To Houthi Attacks
On January 11, the United States and the United Kingdom launched significant strikes against Houthi targets in Yemen as a response to the ongoing Houthi attacks on crucial shipping lanes.
Clear Message To Terrorists
U.S. President Joe Biden stated that these strikes were a clear message that the U.S. would not tolerate attacks on its citizens or threats to navigation.
Also Read:
Former NRA Executive Pleads Guilty to Fraud; Agrees to Testify in New York AG Trial
Uk Prime Minister Chimes In
UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak highlighted the considerable disruption caused to a vital trade route and the resulting increase in commodity prices.
Houthi’s Continue To Strike Back
Despite international actions, the Houthi group in Yemen has affirmed its intention to continue targeting ships bound for Israel.
Impact On Oil Prices
Due to the altered shipping routes in the region, the price of oil surged by 4%. Oil tankers chose to avoid the Red Sea, leading to significant shifts in trade routes and consequently affecting the global oil market.
